description: Chrome, IE, Android & Safari browsers treat forward slashes in URL just like backslashes.
name: Forward slashes

description: One of the most common vectors - http: or https: could be missing, the browser fetches the final URL using the protocol of main document. Works everywhere.
name: Protocol relative

description: Chrome (Linux), Safari and Android treat forward slashes as backslashes, turning the URL into protocol-relative URL. Chrome/Windows treats them as file: protocols and disallows them. IE  treats them as "file:" protocol and tries to forward the requests through WINS resolver (which takes time and can be used as a DoS vector).
name: Protocol relative with forward slashes
Mixed slashes /\
description: Mixed slashes could be used in Chrome, Safari, Android & IE 6, which render this as standard http:// link
Mixed slashes could be used in Chrome, Safari, Android & IE 6, which render this as standard http:// link
name: Mixed slashes \/
White space prefix
description: Any white space (\r, \n, \t and space) before the URL is ignored by all browsers.

name: White space suffix
description: All browsers strip white space after the URL.

name: White space in hostname / path
description: All browsers strip some (\n, \r, \t, not including space) white space characters from inside hostname and path/query, this will reach http://www.google.com/favicon.ico.

name: White space between slashes
description:
All tested browsers strip some white space (
, , 	) even from here - this will reach http://www.google.com/favicon.ico. You could also create 'h
tt	p:/
/' URLs.

name: White space after
description: Trailing whitespace incl. space and a NUL byte (HEX 00,09,0a,0d,20) is stripped completely, the browser will fetch favicon.ico file.
URL encoding is for not meant to be used for protocol, port or host name.
name: %20 encoding

description: This URL is local (it will fetch 'www.google.com' subdirectory).
name: No protocol

description: This URL is local (it will fetch 'www.google.com' subdirectory).
name: Forward slash

description: This URL is local ('http:' will be discarded and it will fetch 'www.google.com' subdirectory). See also #33 and #36.
name: Missing //, current protocol

description: Chrome, Firefox & Safari browsers will try to correct protocols other than current - they will add missing slashes, converting the URL to valid https://. IE & Opera will leave the URL in invalid format. See also #33.
name: Missing //, other protocol

description: Safari will correct the URL even for the curent protocol. Android will leave it in invalid format, all other browsers will convert to internal. See also #33 and #36.
name: Missing /, same protocol
Missing /, other protocol
description: Firefox & Chrome will silently correct 'https:/host' to 'https://host' when your document is on http:// protocol BUT will strip 'https:' converting document URL to local when you're currently on https:// i.e. current protocol is stripped, other protocols are converted. This holds true when serving over https. IE will render an invalid 'https:/host' URL. See also #36.

NULL Unicode byte (\u0000) seems to stop URL processing. Further investigation required. Internet Explorer stops parsing URL at first null byte, so this one effectively transforms to '' being local URL. Android strips NUL characters when processing URLs. Chrome rejects loading URL.
name: NUL byte at the beginning

description: Some browsers allow NULL unicode byte (\u0000) in the middle of the URL, some (Chrome) don't and reject loading the URL. IE ignores the part after NUL.
name: NUL byte in the middle

description: NULL unicode byte (\u0000) can be placed at the end of URL. IE will ignore the NULL byte and everything after it. Chrome strips trailing NULL.
name: NUL byte at the end
Empty two forward slashes
description: This is file: protocol for IE.

name: 4 slashes
description: IE will point to http:////google.com/favicon.ico, Firefox, Chrome and Safari correct the URL. Needs investigation.

name: HTTP Auth tricks
description: IE points to http:////@google.com/. Firefox & Chrome correct the URL. Needs investigation.
Invalid URL for Firefox and Chrome. Needs investigation.
Chrome and Firefox correct the URL.
Pure weirdness. Needs investigation.

name: dot-colon-dot
description: Chrome refuses loading such URL and does nothing. Other browser except mentioned use URL as relative.

name: Spaces in protocol
description: No-go. But see #35.
